awd_titl_txt: Tied migration and anticipatory discrimination against military spouses seeking work
awd_abstract_narration:
Military conflicts create challenges for enlistees and their families. One challenge facing military spouses is that of finding work and maintaining a career in the face of repeated moves and deployments.  This project will reveal whether and the extent to which the public and employers view military spouse job seekers differently than their civilian peers, and if so, how frequent geographic mobility in the past, or assumptions about moves in the future, influence the perceptions of military spouses as job candidates. The project studies how stereotypes of military spouses as frequent movers and job changers may lead to anticipatory discrimination based on presumptions of future behavior when seeking work. Because military spouse employment problems may influence the retention decisions of their service member, this issue has implications for recruiting and retention of a high-quality military force. In doing so, this study offers evidence that may be useful in creating effective policy solutions for military families, as well as other dual income households. 

This study will use complementary experimental and qualitative methods, including survey vignette experiments with actual hiring agents and a series of employer interviews, to identify whether and to what extent hiring agents treat military spouses seeking employment differently than similar civilian peers, and why. The project develops and tests a theory of anticipatory discrimination by explicitly evaluating how past geographic mobility and future expectations of geographic stability influence evaluations of women job seekers, and whether past and future geographic stability accounts for any differential evaluations of military spouse job seekers. The survey experiment is complemented by interviews with actual hiring agents in four labor markets to understand their past experiences with military spouse employees, how they perceive them as applicants, and how hiring decisions are influenced by anticipated futures of these applicants.  The proposed research enhances the study of military spouses and tied migrant labor market outcomes in several ways. First, the project provides explicit attitudinal and behavioral evidence of differential treatment of military spouses relative to civilian spouses. Second, the study broadens the research base on military spouse and tied migrant employment by locating employers as central influences on military spouse unemployment. Third, the proposed research also tests how military spouses and civilian tied migrants are evaluated across labor markets characterized by different levels of military presence. While the case under study centers on one type of worker, similar processes operate with other groups. The concept of anticipatory discrimination may offer new ways to conceive of legal protections for categories of workers based around presumed or actual future statuses.

por.por_cntn:
We use complementary experimental methods across four primary data collection efforts to identify whether and to what military spouses seeking employment are seen and treated differently than similar civilian peers. In doing so, we develop and test a theory of anticipatory discrimination by explicitly evaluating how past geographic mobility and future expectations of geographic stability influence evaluations of women job seekers, and whether past and future geographic stability accounts for any differential evaluations of military spouse job seekers. Four experiments, a survey vignette experiment fielded on both the Amazon?s MTurk worker population and a sample of actual hiring decision makers, a survey and an audit study of hiring, vary military affiliation, past history of geographic mobility, and intentions of future geographic stability, among other key characteristics to identify the relative importance of each in the evaluation and treatment of women job seekers.

We hypothesized:

  • H1: Military spouses will be disadvantaged in hiring and hiring-related evaluations compared to comparable civilian spouses.
    • H1a: The military spouse disadvantage will be greater in military-heavy markets.         
    • H1b: The military spouse disadvantage will be smaller in military-heavy markets.
  • H2: A past history of geographic mobility will be disadvantaged compared to a stable geographic history.
    • H2a: The past mobility penalty will be greater for military spouses.
    • H2b: The past mobility penalty will be smaller for military spouses.
  • H3: The prospect of future geographic stability will be advantaged compared to no explicit mention of future mobility intentions.
    • H3a: The future stability advantage will be greater for military spouses.
    • H3b: The future stability advantage will be smaller for military spouses.
  • H4: The premium for future stability will be lower for those who have a past history of stability.
  • H5: Military spouses will be evaluated/rated with lower expectations of firm longevity than will comparable civilian spouses.

Our factorial vignette analyses confirm several hypothesis tested so far: H1, H2, H2b, H3, H4, and H5. Military spouses received lower hiring recommendation scores (0.52 points lower) than non-military spouses (a military spouse penalty). Women with a past history of geographic stability received higher hiring recommendation scores than did their peers with past geographic mobility by 2.65 points. The military spouse penalty was actually higher among those military spouses with a past history of geographic stability. It seems then that the premium civilian wives gain from a stable residence is not shared equally by military wives, who get less of a benefit from stable residence. We predicted military spouses may be subject to this anticipatory discrimination, in which they are suspect as future movers, and as such, they would not gain as much benefit from past geographic stability. We further test for anticipatory discrimination by evaluating whether military spouses were viewed as less likely to be with the same company in five years. Military spouses were seen as having lower longevity (7.17 points lower) than civilian spouses, and this penalty persisted even after controlling for the other performance expectation measures (3.24 points lower after controls.) Consistent with the theory of anticipatory discrimination, women who explicitly state an intention to remain geographically stable in the future gain a benefit from doing so, showing higher average hiring scores by 1.16 points. When interacting future stability intentions with military spouse status to test whether the premium for future stability is higher for military spouses, we confirm there is an additional premium for military spouses over and above than for civilian spouses. In fact, by stating an intention to remain in the area, military spouses cut the penalty associated with being a military spouse by more than half.    

In our audit study we found more muted effects of past mobility or future stability on the likelihood of receiving a callback in response to a job application. Few differences in treatment were estimated to be statistically different. There is suggestive evidence from this experiment that military spouses seeking jobs may be received more positively in locations with a large military presence than in locations without a large military presence, which would be partly consistent with H1b.

We also conducted a survey-based hiring experiment to try to replicate the summary evaluation of the audit study, but in a survey context. We generally found military spouses to be treated equal to or more positively than their non-military peer with respect to preference to grant an interview, or to offer a job. Thus the evidence is not fully consistent across multiple methods and data sources about the extent of a military spouse penalty. However, the evidence generally supports the theory of anticipatory discrimination, that stereotypes about past geographic mobility and presumptions of future geographic relocations harm all women job seekers, especially military spouses and this operates through the expectation that these women will not be present in the workplace for long, and that they are less ambitious than their peers.
